items.title: Italia sott’acqua ma il Governo non agisce sul clima
items.description:
La disattenzione del governo sulla crisi climatica, che ancora una volta sta devastando il nostro Paese, aumenta l’insicurezza dei cittadini
The post
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie WWF chiede stop allo spreco di fondi per opere inutili Proprio mentre è in corso la COP30 in Brasile, il principale appuntamento internazionale per la lotta al cambiamento climatico, gli eventi estremi di questo fine settimana e quelli in corso, ci ricordano come in Italia non sia più rinviabile affrontare seriamente la crisi climatica, sia in termini di mitigazione (abbattimento delle emissioni di CO2 e metano), sia in termini di adattamento. Il governo invece continua a ritardare e perfino contrastare le azioni contro l’emergenza climatica: così aumenta lo stato di insicurezza della popolazione e il rischio di danni sempre più gravi davanti ai quali i cittadini si sentono sempre più soli. Negli ultimi giorni alluvioni si sono abbattute su diverse regioni del Centro-Nord. Dalla Toscana al Friuli-Venezia Giulia, dalla Liguria al Veneto, questi eventi estremi hanno causato allagamenti, crolli e disagi. Purtroppo, anche la sicurezza delle persone è stata messa a repentaglio: in Friuli-Venezia Giulia, a seguito di una frana di fango che ha travolto un’abitazione risultano al momento disperse due persone, mentre un’altra è stata ferita. I danni sono anche economici: un esempio eclatante arriva purtroppo da Brazzano di Cormons (Gorizia). Tra i tanti cittadini che in queste ore stanno affrontando gravi danni a causa delle piogge torrenziali e delle alluvioni c’è anche la chef stellata Antonia Klugmann, che ha subito l’allagamento dei locali del suo ristorante “L’Argine a Vencò”: a lei e a tutte le persone che si trovano in grave difficoltà va la solidarietà della comunità WWF. Alla Cop 30 il primo documento per contrastare il negazionismo Questi eventi ci ricordano quanto sia importante intervenire per contrastare la crisi climatica. Per farlo serve però che tutti siano costantemente e correttamente informati. Non a caso la scorsa settimana, nel corso della COP30, è stato siglato il primo documento internazionale volto a contrastare la disinformazione e il negazionismo sul cambiamento climatico e a promuovere la diffusione di dati accurati e basati su evidenze scientifiche. Dieci Paesi, tra cui Brasile, Canada, Cile, Danimarca, Finlandia, Francia, Germania, Spagna, Svezia e Uruguay, hanno firmato alla COP30 una Dichiarazione sull’integrità dell’informazione climatica. La dichiarazione, sostenuta dalle Nazioni Unite e dall’Unesco, stabilisce una serie di impegni comuni per garantire la qualità delle informazioni ambientali, finanziando ricerche e programmi di formazione, soprattutto nei Paesi in via di sviluppo. Secondo il segretario generale dell’Onu, António Guterres, la nuova iniziativa globale rappresenta “un passo decisivo per garantire che scienziati e ricercatori non debbano temere di dire la verità”. Il Governo non fa passi avanti per combattere crisi climatica Il WWF si chiede e chiede come mai l’Italia non abbia sottoscritto la dichiarazione. L’azione del governo sul contrasto alla crisi climatica è insoddisfacente. A maggio la Commissione europea ha evidenziato come il Piano Nazionale Integrato per l’Energia e il Clima (PNIEC) dell’Italia abbia al suo interno gravi carenze rispetto agli obiettivi climatici europei e alle raccomandazioni già formulate nel 2023. La valutazione conferma come l’Italia si mostri inadempiente, recependo solo parzialmente le indicazioni di Bruxelles e mancando l’occasione di colmare davvero le profonde lacune già emerse nella versione preliminare del piano. Anche sull’adattamento l’Italia è al palo: non solo non ha nemmeno avviato l’attuazione del Piano nazionale di Adattamento ai Cambiamenti Climatici approvato alla fine del 2023, ma nella legge di Bilancio in discussione in Parlamento risultano ulteriormente tagliati i fondi per affrontare il dissesto idrogeologico. Tutto questo mentre invece l’azione dell’esecutivo si concentra su progetti inutili, dannosi e costosi come il Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina, non a caso recentemente bocciato dalla Corte dei conti. Più in generale il WWF denuncia come il governo sembri deciso a ritardare il più possibile le azioni contro la crisi climatica in nome di un falso pragmatismo che rischia di danneggiare non solo il contrasto alla crisi climatica, ma la stessa competitività economica del Paese. Da quando il governo si è insediato abbiamo visto molte barriere e un forte rallentamento dello sviluppo delle energie rinnovabili, la soluzione per sostituire la causa del problema, cioè i combustibili fossili.

items.title: Future exposure to moist heat extremes linked to soil dryness
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 18 November 2025

Future exposure to moist heat extremes linked to soil dryness
                    Jingwei Zhou1, Dragan Milošević1,2 & Adriaan J. Teuling1

npj Climate and Atmospheric Science

volume 8, Article number: 374 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Atmospheric scienceClimate changeClimate-change impactsClimate sciencesProjection and prediction

AbstractSoil moisture critically modulates moist heat via surface energy fluxes, impacting human health and ecosystems under climate change. Using CMIP6 models with or without interactive soil moisture, we dissect its global role. Moist heat is most severe in tropical and extra-tropical regions, with mid-latitudes showing >2.4 °C increases significantly amplified by soil moisture. Soil moisture dynamics intensify moist heat across most land regions, exhibiting strong negative correlations, especially in eastern South America and Central America. Conversely, diverse moist heat responses to soil moisture variations are found in the Arabian Peninsula and northern Africa. High moist heat generally coincides with high Bowen ratio and low soil moisture while low moist heat is generally found with low Bowen ratio and high moisture. Our findings also highlight exceptions exist where moist heat is not directly influenced by these factors. Critically, soil moisture changes are increasing global population exposure to wet-hot extremes in most regions.

                        IntroductionThe increasing frequency and intensity of moist heat extremes, driven by climate change, are exerting profound impacts on ecosystems, human health, and infrastructure1,2,3. Analysis by Fan et al. (2024) projects an increase in both frequency and intensity of moist heat extremes for most global regions by mid-century (2041–2060) and late-century (2081–2100) relative to the 1995–2014 baseline4. In comparison to dry heatwaves, moist heatwaves are particularly dangerous due to their impact on human physiology, leading to increased incidence of heat-related illnesses and mortality5,6. Approximately one billion people living in urban informal settlements globally are found to be threatened by moist heat extremes7. Soil moisture trends have the possibility to change their impacts on moist heat dynamics under climate change8. Global soil moisture content is found to have roughly equal proportions of drying and wetting in the past decades9, primarily drying regions in broadleaved forests and cropland areas10. While soil moisture trends display marked heterogeneity across soil strata and geographical regions, projections show that global land area is expected to exhibit significant soil moisture reductions11.Soil moisture is a pivotal variable in land-atmosphere interactions, significantly influencing the partitioning of near-surface energy fluxes, which in turn affects both temperature and humidity in the lower atmosphere12,13,14. To quantify moist heat extremes, temperature and relative humidity are the most reliable indicators, as both factors are crucial in the dissipation of heat from the human body through direct heat transfer and sweat evaporation2,15. The impact of soil moisture on temperature has been well-documented over the past decades8,16,17. High soil moisture generally facilitates high evapotranspiration, thereby reducing the energy available for sensible heating. In contrast, low soil moisture conditions associated with drought and (semi-)arid conditions will shift the energy balance towards one that is dominated by sensible heat fluxes rather than evapotranspiration. Higher sensible heat fluxes can amplify heatwave temperatures13,18.Declining soil moisture in general induces higher near-surface air temperature13. However, a primary consequence of reduced soil water content is the suppression of evapotranspiration, which directly limits the amount of moisture transferred from the land surface to the atmosphere, thereby decreasing near-surface relative humidity (Fig. S1)14. In the meantime, warming effect caused by desiccation introduces a secondary, indirect mechanism that further diminishes relative humidity, as warmer air can hold more moisture. Therefore, the impact of soil moisture on moist heat is less straightforward due to the complex feedbacks in the atmospheric boundary layer involving temperature and humidity, and only few studies have attempted to unravel these feedbacks19. Comprehending the intricate relationship between soil moisture and moist heat stress is essential for accurately assessing and mitigating moist heat extremes. In our study, we focus on one widely used index—discomfort index (see Identification and Classification of Moist Heat in Methods), to measure moist heat stress20,21,22,23. The metric incorporates both temperature and relative humidity, providing a measure of heat stress and tolerance levels among populations.Timing of extreme moist heat is critical to accurately assess its global risk. The conventional approach of analyzing a fixed, hemisphere-dependent season (e.g., May to September in northern hemisphere while November to March in southern hemisphere) is inadequate24, as it fails to capture the true period of peak climatological danger in many densely populated and highly vulnerable regions3. For instance, in monsoonal climates such as South Asia, the most life-threatening combinations of heat and humidity frequently occur during the monsoon-onset months (May to July), sometimes before the summer peak25. Utilizing a fixed window would therefore systematically exclude the most severe events in these regions, leading to a substantial underestimation of true regional risk. Our method of dynamically identifying the local peak moist heat season (month with the highest moist heat ± one month) at the grid-cell level is therefore vital. It ensures the analysis is centered on the period of maximum physiological threat specific to each location, providing the necessary credibility to map human exposure to potentially lethal moist heat conditions globally.This study aims to investigate the impacts of soil moisture on moist heat stress at a global scale utilizing the Land Surface, Snow and Soil Moisture Model Intercomparison Project (LS3MIP) dataset within the sixth phase of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP6)26,27. By analyzing historical and future simulations from LS3MIP, we examine the spatial and temporal variations of soil moisture-moist heat coupling and identify regions most susceptible to moist heat stress. Through comparing experiments with or without interactive soil moisture, soil moisture is then isolated to display that its interactions with moist heat are particularly pronounced in hot and humid regions. To our knowledge, this study is the first in using the LS3MIP simulation from the CMIP6 dataset to present a global overview of the interactions between soil moisture and moist heat, in which different peak moist heat seasons are applied in different places. Our research offers novel insights into the role of soil moisture in modulating moist heat stress and underscores the necessity for more accurate representations of land surface processes and feedbacks in climate models. The findings of this study can help in the development of effective strategies to manage and mitigate moist heat risks, and protect vulnerable populations.ResultsValidation of Used CMIP6 DatasetCMIP6 data share similar spatial distributions of moist heat with fifth generation ECMWF atmospheric reanalysis of the global climate (ERA5)-land data (Fig. 1a, c). For example, in general, moist heat decreases as the latitudes increases, except for some high-altitude regions. In the high-altitude regions such as Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, Rocky Mountains, the Andes area, and Greenland, the moist heat is relatively lower than the surrounding areas. CMIP6 results are generally higher than those from ERA5-Land by a value lower than 4.5 °C. However, in those high-altitude regions, the bias between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land results are greater (Fig. 1e). Our selected domains include regions where bias between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land are relatively moderate (Fig. 1e).Fig. 1: Validation of moist heat and soil moisture-moist heat correlations in used CMIP6 datasets.a, b Moist heat a and soil moisture-moist heat correlations b of used CMIP6 datasets in 2000–2020 is depicted. c, d Similar to a, b but for ERA5-Land dataset. e, f Comparisons of moist heat e and soil moisture-moist heat correlations f between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land datasets (CMIP6 minus ERA5-Land). The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. Oceans have been masked in white. MH denotes moist heat and SM denotes soil moisture.Full size imageRegarding soil moisture-moist heat correlations, the spatial distributions between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land are also similar (Fig. 1b, d). Most land regions have negative correlations while in Northern Africa and Arabian Peninsula the correlations are relatively positive (Fig. 1b, d). In the meantime, the bias of that correlation is moderate between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land (Fig. 1f). CMIP6 data show a higher correlation between soil moisture and moist heat compared with ERA5-Land data in most regions. By contrast, within Northern Africa and Arabian Peninsula, most regions reveals that correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are relatively lower in CMIP6 results than those in ERA5-Land (Fig. 1f).Global Moist Heat Hotspots and ChangesChanges and hotspots of global moist heat are investigated using validated climate model data. In the current period (2000–2030), the tropics and extra-tropical regions consistently exhibit more severe moist heat conditions compared to other global areas (Fig. 2a). However, a notable increase in the intensity of moist heat is found in mid-latitude regions (Fig. 2c, S2a–h, q–x, and gg-nn; for example, in Fig. S2f, moist heat intensity is increasing, and in Fig. S2r, more frequent normal wet-hot days become possible in the future), surpassing the magnitude observed in the tropics and extra-tropical regions. These mid-latitude areas, traditionally associated with more temperate climates, are projected to experience significantly more frequent moist heat days in the future (Fig. S2q–x and gg-nn; for example, Fig. S2 shows more normal/extreme wet-hot days in different domains). Nevertheless, tropical and extra-tropical regions still experience a higher intensity and frequency of discomfort indices that exceeds thresholds (the fourth (27 °C)/fifth level (29 °C); Fig. 2b and S2a–h, q–x, and gg-nn).Fig. 2: Changes in moist heat over the 21st century.a, b Moist heat severity is depicted in current period (a; 2000–2030), and future period (b; 2040–2070). c Projected changes of moist heat across two 30-year periods (2000–2030 and 2040–2070). Hatching indicates where the differences between two periods are statistically significant (when p value < 0.05, the differences are regarded as significant; c; AD test). The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. Oceans have been masked in white.Full size imageThe severity of these moist heat conditions highlights the elevated risk of moist heat-related health impacts in certain domains (Fig. 2a), making them key areas of concern in the context of global climate change. The domains, East, South, and Southeast Asia (ESEA), Australia (AU), Eastern United States (EUS), Central America (CAM), Arabian Peninsula (ARP), Mediterranean region and Northern Africa (MNAF), and Eastern South America (ESA), have been identified as hotspots for moist heat stress in our research.Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist HeatSoil moisture impacts on moist heat are studied as well as changes in moist heat per se. Negative, albeit not negligible, correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are found across most terrestrial regions (Fig. 3a, b). In ESA and CAM domains, negative correlations observed are notably stronger compared to other global regions exhibiting negative correlations (Fig. 3a, b), where the ongoing soil desiccation continues to amplify moist heat extremes in the future (Fig. 2, S2 and S3). By contrast, relatively positive correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are found within the ARP, MNAF, and eastern part of EUS domains (Fig. 3a, b), which is particularly noteworthy as it contrasts with the more commonly observed negative correlations in other domains, suggesting unique climatic interactions at play in the ARP and MNAF domains, where water availability and heat stress are critical concerns. All selected domains show an increasing trend in moist heat and wet-hot days, particularly in mid-latitude areas (Fig. 2 and S2). The observed increases in these domains suggest a broader geographic expansion of extreme moist heat conditions, which highlights the emerging vulnerability of mid-latitude regions to moist heat extremes. To understand moist heat trend, soil moisture is critical in its role of influencing regional climate responses. Across many domains, soil moisture changes, including long-term trend of soil moisture and its short-term variability, contribute more to the regional changes of moist heat than the global average (Fig. S2).The relationship between soil moisture and moist heat is not uniform across domains. In current period (2000–2030), the effects of both soil moisture variability and trend are most significant across the MNAF, ESEA, AU, and ESA (Fig. 3c). Differences of soil moisture between pdLC and CTL lead to more responses in moist heat in the future period (2040–2070) across those domains (Fig. 3d, e). Predominantly (semi-)arid regions such as ARP and MNAF indicate that soil moisture increases could potentially mitigate the intensity of moist heat and reduce the frequency of wet-hot days (Fig. 4d, S2, S3, S5b and S10b). Nevertheless, with increasing soil moisture trends (Fig. S3)28,29, mediating effects of soil moisture have a limit and do not change much (soil moisture effects even become less mitigating in some regions; Fig. 3c–e and S2) as expected (more soil moisture increases are accompanied with more moist heat mitigation if the correlation between soil moisture and moist heat is negative), which conforms the fact that positive correlations are found over some regions in ARP and MNAF (Fig. 3a, b). These findings are consistent with some former research results, in which elevated surface humidity are caused by relatively higher soil moisture and increased latent heat flux2,19. Moreover, the advection of humid air masses from neighboring water bodies, such as the Mediterranean Sea or the Red Sea, when combined with high solar radiation and specific boundary layer conditions, may provide the necessary moisture that leads to the observed moderate but positive soil moisture-moist heat correlation in some places2.Sometimes increases in moist heat are not necessarily driven by additional local surface drying with a higher Bowen ratio (Fig. 4a, c, S4, S5, and S7–S10), suggesting that factors other than dry soil can lead to significant thermal stress without further increases in the Bowen ratio. Instead, large-scale atmospheric dynamics often become the dominant factor in leading to significant moist heat stress. By remaining in place for days or even weeks, a blocking high creates a heat dome effect. This pattern leads to prolonged clear skies, allowing for maximum solar radiation, and causes subsidence, where air from higher places in the atmosphere sinks. Lower surface albedo compared with desert in coastal areas also facilitates heating. As the air sinks, it is compressed and warmed adiabatically, significantly increasing surface temperatures over a vast area independent of local soil moisture changes30. The horizontal transport of air, or advection, is another critical factor. Hot, dry air masses originating from desert regions or continental interiors can be transported over long distances. This influx of a pre-heated air mass can rapidly and dramatically increase local temperatures. In such cases, the extreme heat is imported rather than generated by local land-atmosphere energy exchanges, meaning severe moist heat can occur without further changes in the local Bowen ratio31.Similar effects are also particularly pronounced in low-elevation, coastal regions (Fig. S14) of ESEA, AU, CAM, and ESA, where clear skies yield strong solar radiation and contribute to severe moist heat conditions2. Therefore, high moist heat is possible when both Bowen ratio and soil moisture are low (Fig. 4, S4, and S7–S9). However, ESEA, AU, CAM, and ESA exhibit a broader range of soil moisture levels. On the one hand, continuing soil desiccation tends to amplify moist heat in the future (Fig. 4a, e, S2, S4b, and S7b-S9b), from which it is deduced that maintaining soil moisture close to climatological values could further reduce extreme heat (Fig. S3; see Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist Heat in Methods for detailed explanations of the experimental setting). On the other hand, even though higher soil moisture increases evaporation, thereby enhancing relative humidity, it will also mediate near-surface air temperature and in this way moist heat with soil moisture-temperature interactions, which are more evident in ESA and CAM (Figs. S7 and S8). Therefore, moist heat is inhibited with more soil moisture, which facilitate a negative correlation between soil moisture and moist heat, especially in ESA and CAM (Fig. 3, S7, and S8). In conclusion, the complex interplay between soil moisture, near-surface air temperature, and relative humidity underpins the distribution of moist heat across different domains. This interplay underscores the critical role of soil moisture in modulating heat stress and highlights the urgent need for region-specific mitigation strategies to address the escalating impacts of climate change. These findings emphasize the need for more nuanced climate models that can accurately simulate the non-linear and localized interactions between soil moisture and atmospheric conditions.People in most domains are found to be facing more frequent and severe moist heat events (Fig. 5 and S15). The impending threat needs to be recognized in local ability to cope with humid heatwaves and expedite the implementation of mitigating facilities, such as air conditioning systems and urban green spaces, which are crucial for reducing moist heat stress32,33. Interestingly, domains like AU and CAM are expected to see relatively smaller increases in population exposure to moist heat. This is partly due to the fact that, in many areas of both domains, average humid heatwave during maxima seasons will not reach 6 days. However, it is important to note that even in these domains, albeit less than 6 days of all the humid heatwave occurrences during maxima seasons, severe moist heat events remain possible, warranting timely and comprehensive strategies at both governmental and individual levels. In addition, in AU, the projected increases in moist heat are concentrated primarily in inland areas, which are less densely populated compared to coastal regions. Impacts of soil moisture on population exposure to humid heatwaves exhibit complex spatial patterns. Although in most areas, soil moisture changes tend to contribute to more population exposed to humid heatwaves. In MNAF and ARP, soil moisture changes sometimes mitigate population exposure by dampening moist heat (Fig. 3c, d and Fig. 5c, g), though this effect is partly offset in southern Europe due to relatively positive soil moisture-moist heat feedbacks (Fig. 3c, d). In EUS, the continued great contributions from soil moisture post-2000 can be attributed to higher impacts from soil moisture in the middle part (Fig. 3). Additionally, contributions from soil moisture on population exposure to moist heat (Fig. 5) are related to soil moisture’s variations relative to its climatological values (Fig. S3). In domains where soil desiccation strongly amplifies moist heat such as CAM and ESA, soil moisture is projected to decrease and in this way facilitates more population exposure in the future (Fig. 5 and S3).We conclude that our results provided by CMIP6 datasets are a qualitatively robust representation of the large-scale global patterns of the evaluated variables. Bias of moist heat between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land results are moderate, with most regions having a bias lower than 4.5 °C (Fig. 1e). However, in MNAF and ARP, correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are generally lower in CMIP6 compared with ERA5-Land (Fig. 1f), which indicates those positive correlations should be greater but not reflected in our CMIP6 results. Similarly, underestimations of correlations between soil moisture and moist heat exist in other domains. As most regions have negative correlations, the positive bias between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land indicates that the correlations between soil moisture and moist heat ought to be more negative and thus relatively stronger.A critical source of discrepancy lies in the parameterization of soil hydrology. For instance, climate models do not have the same setting of soil profile, they might differ, and in this way have different representation of the soil moisture34,35,36,37. In high-altitude regions, climate models show deficiencies in simulating cold-region hydrological processes, such as the thawing of snowpack and frozen ground. These processes can introduce large volumes of water into the soil column, and misrepresentations of those can lead to significant biases in soil moisture, energy fluxes, and thus moist heat dynamics during the summer season38,39.The choice of maxima season for studying moist heat stress is crucial for accurately assessing the potential impacts on human health and infrastructure. To our knowledge, our study is pioneering in its adoption of different maxima seasons for different regions, which allows us to focus on the periods when moist heat stress is most likely to endanger human health. Moreover, the top 10% of extreme conditions is focused on when evaluating moist heat. This approach ensures that our analysis captures the highest potential impacts, as extreme moist heat events near their upper thresholds are most critical for public health.Effective land management is critical for mitigating humid heatwave impacts on human populations. Irrigation is often highlighted for its ability to modify local soil moisture and reduce temperature extremes, potentially decreasing heatwave exposure for 0.79 to 1.29 billion people40. However, the benefits of irrigation are not universal. In regions where soil moisture and moist heat are positively correlated, particularly where relative humidity exerts more influence, irrigation may inadvertently increase heat stress by raising air humidity (Fig. 3 and S14)41,42. Additionally, water scarcity in arid regions further limits the feasibility of widespread irrigation43,44. While irrigation may be effective in some areas, its use must be carefully calibrated to avoid exacerbating moist heat stress in certain regions.Our analysis is intentionally constrained to the role of soil moisture as a foundational, large-scale driver to moist heat extremes through comparing two experiments with different soil moisture setting (see Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist Heat in Methods). We acknowledge, however, that a complete picture of moist heat modulation requires considering additional anthropogenic or natural forcings. For example, future investigations should integrate the impacts of urbanization, which is a significant driver of observed surface warming at local and regional scales, altering thermal and humidity regimes45. Moreover, a meta-analysis of numerous studies confirms that urban green spaces provide measurable cooling benefits, though their magnitude can vary significantly with park size and vegetation type46. Anthropogenic aerosols are also important factors which influence regional temperature and humidity, through modifying the solar radiation, cloud properties, and precipitation47. A systematic assessment of how these distinct yet interacting drivers collectively modulate the soil moisture-driven moist heat signal is a crucial further step for a holistic risk assessment.In addition, future work will aim to disentangle soil moisture impacts on moist heat by distinguishing between short-term transient fluctuations and long-term drying trends. High-resolution data could complement this analysis by revealing how the variability of soil moisture across different time scales either amplifies or dampens humid heatwaves. However, the broad geographical domains used in this study occasionally mask significant intra-regional heterogeneity in soil moisture’s impact on moist heat. Incorporating higher spatial resolution in climate models would therefore allow future studies to better capture the nuanced interactions between soil moisture and moist heat, particularly in urban environments. Fine-scale spatial differences are critical in evaluating urban settings where microclimates can vary dramatically over short distances due to factors like building density, green space distribution, and water bodies48,49. Higher resolution will enable researchers to better understand how moist heat stress interacts with urban infrastructure and population density and thus identify localized vulnerabilities to moist heat. Moreover, refining the spatial resolution of climate models will facilitate more accurate predictions of moist heat-related impacts on public health and the effectiveness of mitigation strategies such as urban greening and land management practices.MethodsCMIP6 DataIn this study, we utilized daily near-surface air temperature, near-surface relative humidity, surface sensible heat flux, surface latent heat flux, and total soil moisture in the historical experiment, the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP) 585 experiment in Scenario Model Intercomparison Project (ScenarioMIP)50,51, and LFMIP-pdLC experiment of LS3MIP27 from three climate models within CMIP626 (Tab. S1). CMIP6 dataset used in this research has demonstrated robust performance in capturing global soil moisture dynamics and land-atmosphere coupling strength8,27,52,53. LS3MIP is a coordinated experimental framework intended to elucidate the complex interplay between terrestrial surface processes, especially soil moisture, and climate dynamics. This project is set to reveal the critical role of those land surface-climate interactions in affecting atmospheric conditions and modulating extreme events including heatwaves and droughts27. Scenario MIP and historical experiment from CMIP6 is widely used in numerous former studies8,54. The analysis of historical and ScenarioMIP data, referred to hereafter as CTL, minus the LFMIP-pdLC results allows us to isolate the effects of soil moisture changes on moist heat by accounting for both (a) the removal of multidecadal and interannual soil moisture trends and (b) the exclusion of short-term soil moisture variations on sub-seasonal timescale. For consistency, all climate model datasets were interpolated onto a common grid of 2.5° longitude by 1.875° latitude using a conservative remapping technique55. This interpolation enabled the use of a multi-model ensemble mean in our analysis. In this paper, we focus on the pdLC experiment alongside the CTL to quantify the effects of soil moisture changes, represented as CTL–pdLC. CTL experiment features fully coupled and interactive soil moisture. In the corresponding pdLC experiment, by prescribing a repeating seasonal climatology of soil moisture derived from the 1980–2014 control simulation, soil moisture influences can be isolated (detailed information on the CMIP6 experiments can be found in CMIP6 data of Methods)27. Crucially, both simulations are forced with identical sea surface temperature and sea ice conditions, ensuring that any divergence in their outputs can be attributed solely to the soil moisture variability27. To investigate the contribution of soil moisture changes to moist heat and population exposure to it, we examine the comparative moist heat estimates between CTL and pdLC. The decision to compare the period of 2000–2030 with the nearer future period of 2040–2070, rather than a historical period with a more distant future such as 2070–2100, ensures a more relevant investigation of changes in moist heat levels and population exposure to moist heat events. The correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are quantified using the Spearman correlation coefficient57, with statistical significance assessed via the Spearman rho test58. These correlations are calculated using the bias between CTL and pdLC runs. It was generated by replaying the land component of the ERA5 climate reanalysis, driven by atmospheric forcing from the ERA5 atmospheric reanalysis. Here, we use a discomfort index (DI) to classify moist heat64 (21–24 °C, <50% of population in discomfort; 24–27 °C, >50% of population in discomfort; 27–29 °C, most of the population in discomfort; 29–32 °C, everyone feels severe stress; >32 °C, state of emergency)22,65. DI serves as a robust metric for quantifying perceived thermal stress, derived from empirical studies by the U.S. Weather Bureau. Critically, DI demonstrates strong correlation with physiological responses, particularly sweat rates during both rest and exercise, underscoring its relevance in assessing human thermal comfort and potential heat-related health risks66. Modified discomfort index (MDI) is not adopted as it doesn’t correspond to the widely used categories of discomfort we used in this research22,65,67. In addition, DI demonstrates remarkable concordance with the wet-bulb globe temperature (WBGT), a widely-used metric to measure moist heat22,62,63, exhibiting exceptionally high coefficients of determination66.                 where T is the near-surface 2 m air temperature, rh is the near-surface 2 m relative humidity as we focus on the impacts of moist heat on humans’ living condition. WBT is the wet-bulb temperature68. Days with moist heat above or equal with 27 °C and 29 °C are defined as normal wet-hot days and extreme wet-hot days according to the DI levels (Fig. 2a, b), respectively.Apart from tropical regions, moist heat extremes occur mainly from June to August in the Northern Hemisphere and from December to February in the Southern Hemisphere (Fig. S16). Tropical regions, influenced by consistent solar insolation and monsoonal patterns, generally have stable temperature and humidity69. However, monsoons can shift the timing of moist heat, with extreme moist heat preceding or following monsoons70,71. Therefore, we identified the month by ranking monthly mean moist heat values in each grid, focusing on the hottest month and its two adjacent months in our research. The relevant month and season are defined as maxima month and season. As no significant shifts are found in maxima month for moist-heat extremes across future scenarios (Fig. S16)4, we utilized consistent maxima seasons in current and future periods respectively.Our study uniquely adopts different maxima seasons across regions, focusing on the period of most severe moist heat stress. In addition, to quantify moist heat levels, we analyzed the top 10% of occurrences, which is crucial for understanding potential human impacts. When examining the relationship between soil moisture, Bowen ratio, and moist heat, we focused on occurrences where the Bowen ratio exceeds 0 and lies within the lower 90%. This approach minimizes the influences of outliers that skew the Bowen ratio distribution (Fig. S17).Population Dataset and ExposureGiven that population exposure to moist heat is influenced by both demographic factors and moist heat characteristics, our research integrates future population trends to reduce uncertainties in estimating changes in population exposure. To this end, we utilize gridded global population data for the years 2000, 2010, 2020, 2030, 2040, 2050, 2060, and 2070 to assess exposure to moist heat. The dataset, based on the data of 2000, aligns both quantitatively and qualitatively with the SSPs (specifically SSP585 in this study)72,73. The dataset’s spatial resolution is 1/8° by 1/8° in both longitude and latitude. To harmonize the spatial resolution and grid availability between climate and population projections, we aggregate the population data into 2.5° × 1.875° grids by summing the total population within the 1/8° × 1/8° grids that fall within each grid of climate data55. This interpolation facilitates the quantification of population exposure to moist heat, calculated as follows:$${{PE}}_{{percent}}={P}_{a}/{P}_{{all}}$$
                    (5)
                $${{PE}}_{a{bsolute}}={P}_{a}$$
                    (6)
                In a certain region, PEabsolute indicates the population count exposed to moist heat extremes. To better quantify the exposure of populations to increasing moist heat, we also adopted a percentage-based approach with respect to changing local population. In this way, the influences from the demographic shifts can be eliminated, which allows for a robust assessment of population exposure to moist heat. PEpercent indicates the exposed population percentage relative to the total population. Pa indicates the population count which is exposed to average humid heatwaves longer than a certain duration, Pall is the count of the total population.To investigate cumulative heat stress and human acclimatization, apart from solely moist heat stress measurements, we defined normal humid heatwaves as at least 3 consecutive days above 27 °C (normal wet-hot days) and extreme humid heatwaves for 29 °C (extreme wet-hot days). Seasonally humid heatwave duration is calculated as the mean value of each humid heatwave across the whole maxima season of a year. The population exposure to seasonally humid heatwave duration above 6 days and soil moisture impacts on it are quantified in this study.

items.body:
Climate Risk Index 2026: il riscaldamento climatico tra i rischi principali

17.11.2025 -                                 Clima, Cambiamenti Climatici, Emissioni gas serra

condividi:

50 morti e centinaia di migliaia di sfollati, migliaia di case distrutte tra Giamaica e altre isole dei Caraibi: questa l’eredità di Melissa, l’uragano che ha raggiunto categoria 5 (la massima possibile), con venti fino a 300 km/h.

Talmaegi e Fung-Wong sono invece gli ultimi due tifoni (nel solo 2025 ce ne sono stati ben 21) che hanno devastato le Filippine nelle scorse settimane, provocando una decina di morti e portando all’evacuazione di 1 milione e 400 mila persone con danni stimati in oltre 4 miliardi di dollari.

Sono numeri davvero impressionanti, che vanno a confermare un trend che pone le Filippine tra i Paesi più colpiti da eventi estremi negli ultimi anni, così come riportato nel “Climate Risk Index 2026” presentato nel corso della COP 30 in corso a Belém che certifica in modo chiaro come uragani, tifoni e altri eventi estremi stiano diventando sempre più frequenti e intensi così come i loro effetti devastanti.

Il Climate Risk Index, pubblicato fin dal 2006, è un report sugli impatti climatici basato su un indice retrospettivo, che classifica i Paesi del Mondo in base ai danni subiti a causa degli eventi meteorologici estremi (numero di vittime e in generale di persone colpite, danni economici).

Si tratta di una pubblicazione curata da Germanwatch, Organizzazione tedesca indipendente che si occupa di sviluppo, ambiente e diritti umani che in oltre 30 anni di attività di advocacy ha realizzato più di 650 progetti in tutto il mondo spesso risultando fondamentali nel contesto delle politiche di azione per il clima.

Il ranking stila una classifica dei Paesi sulla base degli impatti economici e umani subiti, mettendo nelle prime posizioni chi ha subito maggiormente forti piogge (heavy rainfalls), tempeste devastanti (devastating storms), inondazioni mortali (deadly floods)ma anche caldo torrido (Scorching heat) e incendi (raging wildfires) che abbiano avuto effetti devastanti per le comunità, situazione diventata oggi fin troppo comune in alcuni contesti.

Tra il 1995 e il 2024, il periodo coperto dall'analisi dell'indice che di fatto è anche il trentennio in cui si è provato ad attivare una risposta globale alla crisi climatica tramite le COP, gli oltre 9.700 eventi meteorologici estremi che si sono verificati hanno causato più di 832.000 vittime e hanno portato a perdite economiche dirette per quasi 4,5 trilioni di dollari (valori economici non attualizzati).

L’edizione 2026 del Climate Risk Index https://www.germanwatch.org/en/93310 sottolinea il costo crescente dell'inazione in termini economici ma soprattutto di perdite umane ed evidenzia come la frequenza e l’intensità degli eventi e, di conseguenza, i loro effetti devastanti siano in continuo aumento.

Il ranking appena pubblicato mostra come i Paesi più colpiti da eventi estremi nel corso del 2024 siano stati Saint Vincent e Grenadine, Grenada, Chad, Papua Nuova Guinea, Niger e Nepal.

Se la valutazione si allarga all’intero periodo considerato 1995-2024, ai primi posti si ritrovano Repubblica Domenicana, Myanmar, Honduras, Libia e Haiti.

L’Italia in questa classifica è al sedicesimo posto su 174 paesi mappati.

Il grafico mostra i 20 paesi più colpiti in questo periodo in base ai sei indicatori CRI analizzati (quali: * numero assoluto di vittime; * vittime ogni 100.000 abitanti; * numero assoluto di persone colpite; * persone colpite ogni 100.000 abitanti; * perdite economiche assolute; * perdite economiche relative [in percentuale del PIL]).

Gli eventi estremi hanno una intensità ed una frequenza ("tempo di ritorno") sempre più alta nei medesimi territori, che fanno sempre più fatica a riprendersi tra un evento e l’altro: in termini tecnici significa che l'aumento dei fenomeni estremi abbassa la resilienza dei territori.

Un esempio molto vicino a noi è quanto verificatosi in Emilia-Romagna con le due alluvioni della primavera 2023 e dell’autunno 2024.

Per questo motivo la COP30 si conferma essere un appuntamento fondamentale per il futuro delle nostre comunità.

Il contrasto alla crisi climatica deve passare sia attraverso la mitigazione, vale a dire la riduzione tendente all’azzeramento delle emissioni di gas serra, ma è sempre più importante che ad essa si affianchino azioni di adattamento vale a dire una risposta efficace agli effetti che non è possibile evitare.
